content.description: Hand traverse out the first horizontal (crux) to its end, then make a delicate step up to another horizontal and another step up (crux) to reach a vertical crack as the angle eases.
content.protection: Small to medium cams; tree anchors at top.
content.location: Same as The Flu, at a very shallow concave "groove/face" near the left end of the wall.

content.description: Step up and onto the arête, following up left of the corner to the bulge. Step up and left onto the steep face, swing up and right to gain holds near the edge, and make a tenuous step to reach solid holds in the crack near the top.
content.protection: None. TR set-up is easy on a convenient conifer tree, though a long (15') runner to pass the low-angle slab makes dangling less painful on your rope.
content.location: Right edge of the left side of the Over the Measles Wall. Begin on the right, but step up and around almost immediately onto the slab on the left of the edge.

content.description: Climb up delicate slab to shallow horizontal crack/holds. Traverse left and up to outside corner/arête and then straight up to top.
content.protection: None. Originally free-soloed with a wire brush in one hand, this route has very little, if any protection.
content.location: 10' left of the right outside corner of the left section of the Over the Measles Wall. The start is in or just left of a clean stripe on the slab; a wet streak often makes this start difficult.

content.description: Climb up the outside corner on the left side of the block.
content.protection: None. Use a TR or boulder the entire thing; though falling off this route may precipitate another fall, this down and off the Lower Measles Wall - which would probably be fatal.
content.location: The Over the Measles Wall is divided by a steep gully; this route lies on the small block to the right.

content.description: Climb the very shallow concave face straight up past two horizontal cracks for 12' and continue up the low-angle slab above to trees.
content.location: Left end of cliff.   Descend by scrambling around skier's left.

content.description: The first climbing one reaches when approaching from the trailhead, this cliff lies above the wet, left end of the Lower Measles Wall.   30' tall at its highest, this cliff is unlike its neighbors in that it has very few of the otherwise-ubiquitous and eponymous pockmarks that speckle the rest of the locale.
